entities.description: Paul Ludwig Ewald von Kleist was a German field marshal during World War II. Kleist was the commander of Panzer Group Kleist, the first operational formation of several Panzer corps in the Wehrmacht during the Battle of France, the Battle of Belgium, the Invasion of Yugoslavia and Operation Barbarossa, the invasion of the Soviet Union.

heading: Births
txt: Ladislas Starevich, Russian-French animator, screenwriter, and cinematographer (d. 1965)

entities.title: Ladislas Starevich
entities.description: Ladislas Starevich was a Polish-Russian stop-motion animator notable as the author of the first puppet-animated film The Beautiful Leukanida (1912). He also used dead insects and other animals as protagonists of his films. Following the Russian Revolution, Starevich settled in France.

heading: Births
txt: Sara Teasdale, American poet and educator (d. 1933)

entities.title: Sara Teasdale
entities.description: Sara Teasdale was an American lyric poet. She was born Sarah Trevor Teasdale in St. Louis, Missouri, and used the name Sara Teasdale Filsinger after her marriage in 1914.

entities.title: Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings
entities.description: Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings was an American author who lived in rural Florida and wrote novels with rural themes and settings. Her best known work, The Yearling, about a boy who adopts an orphaned fawn, won a Pulitzer Prize for fiction in 1939 and was later made into a movie of the same name. The book was written long before the concept of young adult fiction, but is now commonly included in teen-rea

heading: Births
txt: Marguerite Bise, French chef (d. 1965)

entities.title: Marguerite Bise
entities.description: Marguerite Valentine Bise was a French chef and restaurateur at her restaurant Auberge du Père Bise in Talloires, Haute-Savoie, France. In 1951, she became the third woman to win three Michelin stars.

heading: Births
txt: Ernest Lawrence, American physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (d. 1958)

entities.title: Ernest Lawrence
entities.description: Ernest Orlando Lawrence was a pioneering American nuclear scientist and winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1939 for his invention of the cyclotron. He is known for his work on uranium-isotope separation for the Manhattan Project, as well as for founding the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. entities.title: Paul Dirac
entities.description: Paul Adrien Maurice Dirac was an English theoretical physicist who is regarded as one of the most significant physicists of the 20th century.

heading: Births
txt: André Jolivet, French composer (d. 1974)

entities.title: André Jolivet
entities.description: André Jolivet was a French composer. Known for his devotion to French culture and musical thought, Jolivet drew on his interest in acoustics and atonality, as well as both ancient and modern musical influences, particularly on instruments used in ancient times. He composed in a wide variety of forms for many different types of ensembles.

heading: Births
txt: Benny Carter, American saxophonist, trumpet player, and composer (d. 2003)

entities.title: Benny Carter
entities.description: Bennett Lester Carter was an American jazz saxophonist, clarinetist, trumpeter, composer, arranger, and bandleader. With Johnny Hodges, he was a pioneer on the alto saxophone. From the beginning of his career in the 1920s he was a popular arranger, having written charts for Fletcher Henderson's big band that shaped the swing style. He had an unusually long career that lasted into the 1990s. During

entities.title: Arthur Goldberg
entities.description: Arthur Joseph Goldberg was an American statesman and jurist who served as the 9th U.S. Secretary of Labor, an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, and the 6th United States Ambassador to the United Nations.

entities.title: United States Ambassador to the United Nations
entities.description: The United States ambassador to the United Nations is the leader of the U.S. delegation, the U.S. Mission to the United Nations. entities.title: Governor-General of New Zealand
entities.description: The governor-general of New Zealand is the viceregal representative of the monarch of New Zealand, currently Queen Elizabeth II. entities.description: The Premier of New South Wales is the head of government in the state of New South Wales, Australia. The Government of New South Wales follows the Westminster system, with a Parliament of New South Wales acting as the legislature. LeNoire is known to contemporary audiences for her work in television. She had regular roles on the series Gimme a Break! and Amen, and is best known for her role as Estelle "Mother Winslow" on Family Matters, which ran from 1989 to 1998. heading: Births
txt: James Elliott, American runner and coach (d. 1981)

entities.title: Jumbo Elliott (coach)
entities.description: James F. "Jumbo" Elliott was an American track and field coach, often considered to be one of the greatest of all time. His achievements include producing five Olympic gold medal winners between 1956 and 1968.

heading: Births
txt: Dino De Laurentiis, Italian actor and producer (d. 2010)

entities.title: Dino De Laurentiis
entities.description: Agostino "Dino" De Laurentiis was an Italian film producer. Along with Carlo Ponti, he was one of the producers who brought Italian cinema to the international scene at the end of World War II. He produced or co-produced more than 500 films, of which 38 were nominated for Academy Awards. He also had a brief acting career in the late 1930s and early 1940s.

entities.title: Monokini
entities.description: The monokini, designed by Rudi Gernreich in 1964, consisting of only a brief, close-fitting bottom and two thin straps, was the first women's topless swimsuit. His revolutionary and controversial design included a bottom that "extended from the midriff to the upper thigh" and was "held up by shoestring laces that make a halter around the neck." He served in this role until 1996, when he became a member of the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, serving until 2000.

According to Article V of the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Presidency comprises three members: one Bosniak, one Serb, and one Croat. entities.title: Shawn Mendes
entities.description: Shawn Peter Raul Mendes is a Canadian singer and songwriter. He gained a following in 2013, posting song covers on the video-sharing application Vine. The following year, he caught the attention of artist manager Andrew Gertler and Island Records A&R Ziggy Chareton, which led to him signing a deal with the record label. Mendes's self-titled debut EP was released in 2014, followed by his debut stud

heading: Births
txt: Ryan Garcia, American Boxer

heading: Births
txt: Félix Auger-Aliassime, Canadian tennis player

entities.title: Félix Auger-Aliassime
entities.description: Félix Auger-Aliassime is a Canadian professional tennis player. He is the second-youngest player ranked in the top 20 by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP), and has a career-high ranking of No. 17 in the world. He has seven runner-up finishes in singles and one doubles title on the ATP Tour.

heading: Deaths
txt: Trajan, Roman emperor (b. 53)

entities.title: Trajan
entities.description: Trajan was Roman emperor from 98 to 117. Officially declared by the Senate optimus princeps, Trajan is remembered as a successful soldier-emperor who presided over the second-greatest military expansion in Roman history, after Augustus, leading the empire to attain its maximum territorial extent by the time of his death. He is also known for his philanthropic rule, overseeing extensive public buil

heading: Deaths
txt: Hildegar, bishop of  Cologne

entities.title: Hildegar (bishop of Cologne)
entities.description: Hildegar was the bishop of Cologne from 750. Probably of noble birth, he was a supporter of the Carolingians, who displaced the Merovingians in 751.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lothair II, Frankish king (b. 835)

entities.title: Lothair II
entities.description: Lothair II was the king of Lotharingia from 855 until his death. He was the second son of Emperor Lothair I and Ermengarde of Tours. He was married to Teutberga, daughter of Boso the Elder.

heading: Deaths
txt: Seo Hui, Korean politician and diplomat (b. 942)

entities.title: Seo Hui
entities.description: Seo Hui was a Korean politician and diplomat during the early days of the Goryeo Dynasty of Korea (918–1392). Seo is best remembered for his diplomatic skills that led 60,000 Khitan troops to withdraw from Goryeo without a battle.

heading: Deaths
txt: Almanzor, chief minister and de facto ruler of Córdoba

entities.title: Almanzor
entities.description: Abu ʿĀmir Muḥammad ibn ʿAbdullāh ibn Abi ʿĀmir al-Maʿafiri, nicknamed  al-Manṣūr, usually simply called Almanzor, was a Muslim Arab Andalusian military leader and statesman. As the chancellor of the Umayyad Caliphate of Córdoba and hajib (chamberlain) for the weak Caliph Hisham II, Almanzor was the de facto ruler of Islamic Iberia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry of Blois, bishop of Winchester (b. 1111)

entities.title: Henry of Blois
entities.description: Henry of Blois, often known as Henry of Winchester, was Abbot of Glastonbury Abbey from 1126, and Bishop of Winchester from 1129 to his death. He was a younger son of Stephen Henry, Count of Blois by Adela of Normandy, daughter of William the Conqueror and Matilda of Flanders. Thus, he was a younger brother of Stephen, King of England.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry of Castile the Senator, Spanish nobleman (b. 1230)

entities.title: Henry of Castile the Senator
entities.description: Henry of Castile, called the Senator, was a Castilian infante, the fourth son of Ferdinand III of Castile by his first wife, Beatrice of Swabia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lucas van Leyden, Dutch artist (b. 1494)

entities.title: Lucas van Leyden
entities.description: Lucas van Leyden, also named either Lucas Hugensz or Lucas Jacobsz, was a Dutch painter and printmaker in engraving and woodcut. Lucas van Leyden was among the first Dutch exponents of genre painting and was a very accomplished engraver.

heading: Deaths
txt: Oronce Finé, French mathematician and cartographer (b. 1494)

entities.title: Oronce Finé
entities.description: Oronce Finé was a French mathematician and cartographer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alonso Sánchez Coello, Spanish painter (b. 1532)

entities.title: Alonso Sánchez Coello
entities.description: Alonso Sánchez Coello was an Iberian portrait painter of the Spanish and Portuguese Renaissance. He is mainly known for his portrait paintings executed in a style which combines the objectivity of the Flemish tradition with the sensuality of Venetian painting. He was court painter to Philip II.

heading: Deaths
txt: Horio Tadauji, Japanese daimyō (b. 1578)

entities.title: Horio Tadauji
entities.description:
Horio Tadauji 
was a tozama daimyō in the Azuchi–Momoyama and Edo period.
His father was Horio Yoshiharu.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cornelis Ketel, Dutch painter (b. 1548)

entities.title: Cornelis Ketel
entities.description: Cornelis or Cornelius Ketel was a Dutch Mannerist painter, active in Elizabethan London from 1573 to 1581, and in Amsterdam till his death. Ketel, known essentially as a portrait-painter, was also a poet and orator, and from 1595 a sculptor as well.

heading: Deaths
txt: Konstantinas Sirvydas, Lithuanian priest, lexicographer, and academic (b. 1579)

entities.title: Konstantinas Sirvydas
entities.description: Konstantinas Sirvydas was a Lithuanian religious preacher, lexicographer and one of the pioneers of Lithuanian literature from the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, at the time a confederal part of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth. He was a Jesuit priest, a professor at the Academia Vilnensis and the author of, among other works, the first grammar of the Lithuanian language and the first tri-lingual dic

heading: Deaths
txt: George Booth, 1st Baron Delamer, English politician (b. 1622)

entities.title: George Booth, 1st Baron Delamer
entities.description: George Booth, 1st Baron Delamer, was an English landowner and politician from Cheshire, who served as an MP from 1646 to 1661, when he was elevated to the House of Lords as Baron Delamer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Christoph Ludwig Agricola, German painter (b. 1667)

entities.title: Christoph Ludwig Agricola
entities.description: Christoph Ludwig Agricola was a German landscape painter and etcher. He was born and died at Regensburg (Ratisbon).

heading: Deaths
txt: Madeleine de Verchères, Canadian raid leader (b. 1678)

entities.title: Madeleine de Verchères
entities.description: Marie-Madeleine Jarret, known as Madeleine de Verchères was a woman of New France credited with repelling a raid on Fort Verchères when she was 14 years old.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francis Hutcheson, Irish philosopher (b. 1694)

entities.title: Francis Hutcheson (philosopher)
entities.description: Francis Hutcheson was an Irish philosopher born in Ulster to a family of Scottish Presbyterians who became known as one of the founding fathers of the Scottish Enlightenment. He is remembered for his book A System of Moral Philosophy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Heinrich Graun, German tenor and composer (b. 1704)

entities.title: Carl Heinrich Graun
entities.description: Carl Heinrich Graun was a German composer and tenor. Along with Johann Adolph Hasse, he is considered to be the most important German composer of Italian opera of his time.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Canning, English lawyer and politician, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom (b. 1770)

entities.title: George Canning
entities.description: George Canning was a British Tory statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from April to August 1827. He occupied various senior cabinet positions under numerous prime ministers, finally becoming Prime Minister for the last 118 days of his life.

entities.title: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
entities.description: The prime minister of the United Kingdom is the head of government in the United Kingdom. The prime minister chairs the Cabinet and selects its ministers, and advises the sovereign on the exercise of much of the Royal Prerogative. As modern prime ministers hold office by virtue of their ability to command the confidence of the House of Commons, they typically sit as a Member of Parliament and lead

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Peter Thunberg, Swedish botanist and psychologist (b. 1743)

entities.title: Carl Peter Thunberg
entities.description: Carl Peter Thunberg, also known as Karl Peter von Thunberg, Carl Pehr Thunberg, or Carl Per Thunberg, was a Swedish naturalist and an "apostle" of Carl Linnaeus. After studying under Linnaeus at Uppsala University, he spent seven years travelling in southern Africa and Asia, collecting and describing many plants and animals new to European science, and observing local cultures. He has been called

heading: Deaths
txt: Marie-Claire Heureuse Félicité Bonheur, Haitian Empress (b. 1758)

entities.title: Marie-Claire Heureuse Félicité
entities.description: Empress Marie-Claire Heureuse Félicité Bonheur, Empress of Hayti was the Empress of Haiti (1804–1806) as the spouse of Jean-Jacques Dessalines.

heading: Deaths
txt: Angus MacAskill, Scottish-Canadian giant (b. 1825)

entities.title: Angus MacAskill
entities.description: Angus MacAskill was a Scottish-born Canadian giant. The 1981 Guinness Book of World Records says he is the tallest non-pathological giant in recorded history and had the largest chest measurements of any non-obese man.

heading: Deaths
txt: Immanuel Hermann Fichte, German philosopher and academic (b. 1797)

entities.title: Immanuel Hermann Fichte
entities.description: Immanuel Hermann Fichte was a German philosopher and son of Johann Gottlieb Fichte. In his philosophy, he was a theist and strongly opposed to the Hegelian School.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander William Doniphan, American colonel, lawyer, and politician (b. 1808)

entities.title: Alexander William Doniphan
entities.description: Alexander William Doniphan was a 19th-century American attorney, soldier and politician from Missouri who is best known today as the man who prevented the summary execution of Joseph Smith, founder of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, at the close of the 1838 Mormon War in that state. He also achieved renown as a leader of American troops during the Mexican–American War, as the auth

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacob Burckhardt, Swiss historian and academic (b. 1818)

entities.title: Jacob Burckhardt
entities.description: Carl Jacob Christoph Burckhardt was a Swiss historian of art and culture and an influential figure in the historiography of both fields. He is known as one of the major progenitors of cultural history. Sigfried Giedion described Burckhardt's achievement in the following terms: "The great discoverer of the age of the Renaissance, he first showed how a period should be treated in its entirety, with

heading: Deaths
txt: Eugène Boudin, French painter (b. 1824)

entities.title: Eugène Boudin
entities.description: Eugène Louis Boudin was one of the first French landscape painters to paint outdoors. Boudin was a marine painter, and expert in the rendering of all that goes upon the sea and along its shores. His pastels, summary and economic, garnered the splendid eulogy of Baudelaire; and Corot called him the "King of the skies".

heading: Deaths
txt: James Tissot, French painter and illustrator (b. 1836)

entities.title: James Tissot
entities.description: Jacques Joseph Tissot, Anglicized as James Tissot, was a French painter and illustrator. He was a successful painter of Paris society before moving to London in 1871. He became famous as a genre painter of fashionably dressed women shown in various scenes of everyday life. He also painted scenes and characters from the Bible.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Henry Twachtman, American painter and academic (b. 1853)

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary MacKillop, Australian nun and saint, co-founded the Sisters of St Joseph of the Sacred Heart (b. 1842)

entities.title: Mary MacKillop
entities.description: Mary Helen MacKillop RSJ was an Australian religious sister who has been declared a saint by the Catholic Church, as St Mary of the Cross. Of Scottish descent, she was born in Melbourne but is best known for her activities in South Australia. Together with Julian Tenison-Woods, she founded the Sisters of St Joseph of the Sacred Heart, a congregation of religious sisters that established a number o

entities.title: Sisters of St Joseph of the Sacred Heart
entities.description: The Sisters of St Joseph of the Sacred Heart, often called the "Josephites" or "Brown Joeys", were founded in Penola, South Australia, in 1866 by Mary MacKillop and the Rev. Julian Tenison Woods. Members of the congregation use the postnominal initials RSJ.

heading: Deaths
txt: William P. Frye, American lawyer and politician (b. 1830)

entities.title: William P. Frye
entities.description: William Pierce Frye was an American politician from Maine. Frye, a member of the Republican Party, spent most of his political career as a legislator, serving in the Maine House of Representatives and then U.S. House of Representatives, before being elected to the U.S. Senate, where he served for 30 years; dying in office. Frye was a member of the Frye political family, and was the grandfather of

heading: Deaths
txt: Eduard Birnbaum, Polish-born German cantor (b. 1855)

entities.title: Eduard Birnbaum
entities.description: Eduard Birnbaum (1855–1920) was a Polish-born German hazzan (cantor) and one of the first explorers of Jewish music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Juhani Aho, Finnish journalist and author (b. 1861)

entities.title: Juhani Aho
entities.description: Juhani Aho, originally Johannes Brofeldt, was a Finnish–Swedish author and journalist. He was nominated for the Nobel prize in literature twelve times.

heading: Deaths
txt: Stjepan Radić, Croatian politician (b. 1871)

entities.title: Stjepan Radić
entities.description: Stjepan Radić was a Croatian politician and founder of the Croatian People's Peasant Party (HPSS).

heading: Deaths
txt: Launceston Elliot, Scottish wrestler and weightlifter (b. 1874)

entities.title: Launceston Elliot
entities.description: Launceston Elliot was a Scottish weightlifter, and the first British Olympic champion.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wilbert Robinson, American baseball player, coach, and manager (b. 1863)

entities.title: Wilbert Robinson
entities.description: Wilbert Robinson, nicknamed "Uncle Robbie", was an American catcher, coach and manager in Major League Baseball (MLB). He played in MLB for the Philadelphia Athletics, Baltimore Orioles, and St. Louis Cardinals. He managed the Orioles and Brooklyn Robins. Robinson was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1945.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jimmie Guthrie, Scottish motorcycle racer (b. 1897)

entities.title: Jimmie Guthrie
entities.description: James Guthrie was a Scottish motorcycle racer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johnny Dodds, American clarinet player and saxophonist (b. 1892)

entities.title: Johnny Dodds
entities.description: Johnny Dodds was an American jazz clarinetist and alto saxophonist based in New Orleans, best known for his recordings under his own name and with bands such as those of Joe "King" Oliver, Jelly Roll Morton, Lovie Austin and Louis Armstrong. Dodds was the older brother of the drummer Warren "Baby" Dodds, one of the first important jazz drummers. They worked together in the New Orleans Bootblacks i

heading: Deaths
txt: Erwin von Witzleben, German field marshal (b. 1881)

entities.title: Erwin von Witzleben
entities.description: Job Wilhelm Georg Erdmann Erwin von Witzleben was a German field marshal in the Wehrmacht during the Second World War. A leading conspirator in the 20 July plot to assassinate Adolf Hitler, he was designated to become Commander-in-Chief of the Wehrmacht in a post-Nazi regime had the plot succeeded.

heading: Deaths
txt: Michael Wittmann, German commander (b. 1914)

heading: Deaths
txt: Anton Denikin, Russian general (b. 1872)

entities.title: Anton Denikin
entities.description: Anton Ivanovich Denikin was a Russian Lieutenant General in the Imperial Russian Army (1916), later served as the Deputy Supreme Ruler of Russia during the Russian Civil War of 1917–1922. He was also a military leader of South Russia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fergus McMaster, Australian businessman, founded Qantas (b. 1879)

entities.title: Fergus McMaster
entities.description: Sir Fergus McMaster was an Australian businessman and aviation pioneer. He was one of the three founders of the Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Services Limited, the airline company that became commonly known by its acronym, Qantas.

entities.title: Qantas
entities.description: Qantas Airways Limited is the flag carrier of Australia and its largest airline by fleet size, international flights and international destinations. It is the world's third-oldest airline still in operation, having been founded in November 1920; it began international passenger flights in May 1935. The Qantas name comes from "QANTAS", an acronym for its original name, Queensland and Northern Terri

heading: Deaths
txt: Albert Namatjira, Australian painter (b. 1902)

entities.title: Albert Namatjira
entities.description: Albert Namatjira was an Aboriginal artist from the MacDonnell Ranges in Central Australia. As a pioneer of contemporary Indigenous Australian art, he was the most famous Indigenous Australian of his generation.

heading: Deaths
txt: Shirley Jackson, American novelist and short story writer (b. 1916)

entities.title: Shirley Jackson
entities.description: Shirley Hardie Jackson was an American writer, known primarily for her works of horror and mystery. Over the duration of her writing career, which spanned over two decades, she composed six novels, two memoirs, and more than 200 short stories.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otmar Freiherr von Verschuer, German biologist and eugenicist (b. 1896)

entities.title: Otmar Freiherr von Verschuer
entities.description: Otmar Freiherr von Verschuer was a German human biologist, national socialist, and geneticist, who was the Professor of Human Genetics at the University of Münster until he retired in 1965. A member of the Dutch noble Verschuer family, his title Freiherr is often translated as baron.

heading: Deaths
txt: Freddie Spencer Chapman, English lieutenant (b. 1907)

entities.title: Freddie Spencer Chapman
entities.description: Frederick Spencer Chapman, DSO & Bar, ED was a British Army officer and World War II veteran, most famous for his exploits behind enemy lines in Japanese occupied Malaya. His medals include the following: the Distinguished Service Order and Bar, the Polar Medal, Gill Memorial Medal, Mungo Park Medal, and the Lawrence of Arabia Memorial Medal.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vilhelm Moberg, Swedish historian and author (b. 1898)

entities.title: Vilhelm Moberg
entities.description: Karl Artur Vilhelm Moberg was a Swedish journalist, author, playwright, historian, and debater. His literary career, spanning more than 45 years, is associated with his series The Emigrants. The four books, published between 1949 and 1959, deal with the Swedish emigration to the United States in the 19th century, and are the subject of two movie adaptations and a musical. Among other works are Ras

heading: Deaths
txt: Elisabeth Abegg, German anti-Nazi resistance fighter (b. 1882)

entities.title: Elisabeth Abegg
entities.description: Luise Wilhelmine Elisabeth Abegg was a German educator and resistance fighter against Nazism. She provided shelter to around 80 Jews during the Holocaust and was consequently recognised as Righteous Among the Nations.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cannonball Adderley, American saxophonist (b. 1928)

entities.title: Cannonball Adderley
entities.description: Julian Edwin "Cannonball" Adderley was an American jazz alto saxophonist of the hard bop era of the 1950s and 1960s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicholas Monsarrat, English lieutenant and author (b. 1910)

entities.title: Nicholas Monsarrat
entities.description: Lieutenant Commander Nicholas John Turney Monsarrat FRSL RNVR was a British novelist known for his sea stories, particularly The Cruel Sea (1951) and Three Corvettes (1942–45), but perhaps known best internationally for his novels, The Tribe That Lost Its Head and its sequel, Richer Than All His Tribe.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Triquet, Canadian general, Victoria Cross recipient (b. 1910)

entities.title: Paul Triquet
entities.description: Brigadier-General Paul Triquet, born in Cabano, Quebec, was a Canadian recipient of the Victoria Cross (VC), the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces. Triquet held the rank of captain at the time of his VC award, and went on to achieve the rank of brigadier-general.

entities.title: Victoria Cross
entities.description: The Victoria Cross (VC) is the highest and most prestigious award of the British honours system. It is awarded for valour "in the presence of the enemy" to members of the British Armed Forces. It may be awarded posthumously. It was previously awarded to Commonwealth countries, most of which have established their own honours systems and no longer recommend British honours. It may be awarded to a p

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas McElwee, Irish republican and PIRA volunteer (b. 1957)

entities.title: Thomas McElwee
entities.description: Thomas McElwee was an Irish republican who participated in the 1981 hunger strike and a volunteer in the Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA). From Bellaghy, County Londonderry, Northern Ireland, he died at the age of 23 after 62 days on hunger strike.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eric Brandon, English racing driver and businessman (b. 1920)

entities.title: Eric Brandon
entities.description: Eric Brandon was a motor racing driver and businessman. He was closely associated with the Cooper Car Company, and was instrumental in the early development of the company.

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Deacon, American actor (b. 1921)

entities.title: Richard Deacon (actor)
entities.description: Richard Deacon was an American television and motion picture actor, best known for playing supporting roles in television shows such as The Dick Van Dyke Show, Leave It To Beaver, and The Jack Benny Program along with minor roles in films such as Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1956) and Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ellen Raskin, American author and illustrator (b. 1928)

heading: Deaths
txt: Louise Brooks, American actress (b. 1906)

entities.title: Louise Brooks
entities.description: Mary Louise Brooks, known professionally as Louise Brooks, was an American film actress and dancer during the 1920s and 1930s. She is regarded today as a Jazz Age icon and as a flapper sex symbol due to her bob hairstyle that she helped popularize during the prime of her career.

heading: Deaths
txt: Danilo Blanuša, Croatian mathematician and physicist (b. 1903)

entities.title: Danilo Blanuša
entities.description: Danilo Blanuša was a Yugoslav mathematician, physicist, engineer and a professor at the University of Zagreb, SR Croatia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Félix Leclerc, Canadian singer-songwriter and guitarist (b. 1914)

entities.title: Félix Leclerc
entities.description: Félix Leclerc, was a French-Canadian singer-songwriter, poet, writer, actor and Québécois political activist. He was made an Officer of the Order of Canada on December 20, 1968. Leclerc was posthumously inducted into the Canadian Songwriters Hall of Fame for his songs "Moi, mes souliers", "Le P'tit Bonheur" and "Le Tour de l'île" in 2006.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alan Napier, English actor (b. 1903)

heading: Deaths
txt: James Irwin, American colonel, pilot, and astronaut (b. 1930)

entities.title: James Irwin
entities.description: Col. James Benson Irwin, USAF was an American astronaut, aeronautical engineer, test pilot, and a United States Air Force pilot. He served as Apollo Lunar Module pilot for Apollo 15, the fourth human lunar landing. He was the eighth person to walk on the Moon and the first, and youngest, of those astronauts to die.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abu al-Qasim al-Khoei, Iranian religious leader and scholar (b. 1899)

entities.title: Abu al-Qasim al-Khoei
entities.description: Grand Ayatollah Sayyid Abu al-Qasim al-Musawi al-Khoei was an Iranian-Iraqi Shia marja'. al-Khoei is considered one of the most influential twelver scholars.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nevill Francis Mott, English physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1905)

entities.title: Nevill Francis Mott
entities.description: Sir Nevill Francis Mott was a British physicist who won the Nobel Prize for Physics in 1977 for his work on the electronic structure of magnetic and disordered systems, especially amorphous semiconductors. The award was shared with Philip W. Anderson and J. H. Van Vleck. The three had conducted loosely related research. Mott and Anderson clarified the reasons why magnetic or amorphous materials ca

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Jüri Randviir, Estonian chess player and journalist (b. 1927)

heading: Deaths
txt: Mahmoud Saremi, Iranian journalist (b. 1968)

entities.title: Mahmoud Saremi
entities.description: Mahmoud Saremi was an Iranian reporter, working for IRNA, as the news agency's head of office in Mazari Sharif. He was killed by the Taliban when they occupied the Iranian consulate in Mazari Sharif, together with eight Iranian diplomats.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dirk Hoogendam, Dutch-German SS officer (b. 1922)

entities.title: Dirk Hoogendam
entities.description: Dirk Hoogendam, a.k.a. Dieter Hohendamm, alias The Boxer, was a Dutch war criminal.

entities.title: SS
entities.description: The Schutzstaffel was a major paramilitary organization under Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party in Nazi Germany, and later throughout German-occupied Europe during World War II. It began with a small guard unit known as the Saal-Schutz made up of party volunteers to provide security for party meetings in Munich. In 1925, Heinrich Himmler joined the unit, which had by then been reformed and given its

heading: Deaths
txt: Falaba Issa Traoré, Malian director and playwright (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Leon Golub, American painter and academic (b. 1922)

entities.title: Leon Golub
entities.description: Leon Golub was an American painter. He was born in Chicago, Illinois, where he also studied, receiving his BA at the University of Chicago in 1942, and his BFA and MFA at the Art Institute of Chicago in 1949 and 1950, respectively.

heading: Deaths
txt: Fay Wray, Canadian-American actress (b. 1907)

heading: Deaths
txt: Barbara Bel Geddes, American actress (b. 1922)

entities.title: Barbara Bel Geddes
entities.description: Barbara Bel Geddes was an American stage and screen actress, artist, and children's author whose career spanned almost five decades. She was best known for her starring role as Miss Ellie Ewing in the television series Dallas. Bel Geddes also starred as Maggie in the original Broadway production of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof in 1955. Her notable films included I Remember Mama (1948) and Vertigo (1958).

heading: Deaths
txt: Ahmed Deedat, South African missionary and author (b. 1918)

heading: Deaths
txt: John H. Johnson, American publisher, founded the Johnson Publishing Company (b. 1918)

entities.title: Johnson Publishing Company
entities.description: Johnson Publishing Company, Inc. (JPC) was an American publishing company founded in November 1942 by African-American businessman John H. Johnson. It was headquartered in Chicago, Illinois. JPC was privately held and run by Johnson until his death in 2005. Led by its flagship publication, Ebony, Johnson Publishing was at one time the largest African-American-owned publishing firm in the United St

heading: Deaths
txt: Gene Mauch, American baseball player and manager (b. 1925)

heading: Deaths
txt: Dean Rockwell, American commander, wrestler, and coach (b. 1912)

heading: Deaths
txt: Monica Sjöö, Swedish-English painter (b. 1938)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ma Lik, Chinese journalist and politician (b. 1952)

entities.title: Ma Lik
entities.description: Ma Lik, GBS, JP, was a Legislative Councillor, and was the Chairman of the Democratic Alliance for Betterment of Hong Kong (DAB), a pro-Beijing political party in Hong Kong.

heading: Deaths
txt: Melville Shavelson, American director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1917)

heading: Deaths
txt: Orville Moody, American golfer (b. 1933)

entities.title: Orville Moody
entities.description: Orville James Moody was an American professional golfer who won numerous tournaments in his career. He won the U.S. Open in 1969, the last champion in the 20th century to win through local and sectional qualifying.

heading: Deaths
txt: Daniel Jarque, Spanish footballer (b. 1983)

entities.title: Daniel Jarque
entities.description: Daniel Jarque González was a Spanish professional footballer who played as a central defender.

heading: Deaths
txt: Patricia Neal, American actress (b. 1926)

entities.title: Patricia Neal
entities.description: Patricia Neal was an American actress of stage and screen. She was best known for her film roles as World War II widow Helen Benson in The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951), radio journalist Marcia Jeffries in A Face in the Crowd (1957), wealthy matron Emily Eustace Failenson in Breakfast at Tiffany's (1961), and the worn-out housekeeper Alma Brown in Hud (1963), for which she won the Academy Award

heading: Deaths
txt: Fay Ajzenberg-Selove, German-American physicist and academic (b. 1926)

entities.title: Fay Ajzenberg-Selove
entities.description: Fay Ajzenberg-Selove was an American nuclear physicist. She was known for her experimental work in nuclear spectroscopy of light elements, and for her annual reviews of the energy levels of light atomic nuclei. She was a recipient of the 2007 National Medal of Science.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ruth Etchells, English poet and academic (b. 1931)

entities.title: Karen Black
entities.description: Karen Blanche Black was an American actress, screenwriter, singer, and songwriter. She rose to prominence for her work in various studio and independent films in the 1970s, frequently portraying eccentric and offbeat characters, and established herself as a figure of New Hollywood. heading: Deaths
txt: Menahem Golan, Israeli director and producer (b. 1929)

entities.title: Menahem Golan
entities.description: Menahem Golan was an Israeli film producer, screenwriter, and director. He was best known for co-owning The Cannon Group with his cousin Yoram Globus. Cannon specialized in producing low-to-mid-budget American films, primarily Genre films, during the 1980s after Golan and Globus had achieved significant filmmaking success in their native Israel during the 1970s.

entities.title: Glen Campbell

He was best known for a series of hit songs in the 1960s and 1970s, and for hosting The Glen Campbell Goodtime Hour on CBS television from 1969 until 1972. heading: Deaths
txt: Nicholas Bett, Kenyan track and field athlete (b. 1990)

entities.title: Nicholas Bett
entities.description: Nicholas Kiplagat Bett was a Kenyan track and field athlete who competed in the 400 metres hurdles. His personal best for the event is 47.79 seconds. He was a world champion in the event, having won in 2015, and a two-time bronze medallist at the African Championships in Athletics. He died in a road accident in Kenya at the age of 28.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gabriel Ochoa Uribe, Colombian football player and manager (b. 1929)

entities.title: Gabriel Ochoa Uribe
entities.description: Gabriel Ochoa Uribe was a Colombian football player and manager. He won four league titles and the Copa Colombia with Millonarios as a player and fourteen league titles as a manager, making him the most successful Colombian coach of all time.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfredo Lim, former Philippine senator and Mayor of Manila (b. 1929)

entities.title: List of senators of the Philippines
entities.description: The Senate of the Philippines is the upper house of Congress. The senate composed of 24 senators, each elected in to a six-year term, with one re-election under plurality-at-large voting: on each election, the voters vote for up to twelve candidates, with the twelve candidates the highest number of votes being elected in.

entities.title: Mayor of Manila
entities.description: The city mayor of Manila is the head of the executive branch of the Manila's government. The mayor holds office at Manila City Hall. Like all local government heads in the Philippines, the mayor is elected via popular vote, and may not be elected for a fourth consecutive term. In case of death, resignation or incapacity, the vice mayor becomes the mayor.
